WRITING.TITLE: I'm not sure a Christian therapist is going to do me any good?
WRITING.TEXT: Background: I was taken advantage of three years ago by my [now] ex boyfriend. I managed to shove it into the back of my mind and vowed never to think about it again, partly because at that time I was blaming myself for not stopping him and partly because when I told a friend, he told me that I probably imagined that because my ex would never do something like that. I'm now in a good relationship, but I've started getting flashbacks when we have sex. Not every time, but often enough that it scares me to have sex even though I have a strong sex drive. My boyfriend is very understanding and is always telling me that he'll stop if I get a flashback and that it's not a problem, but I feel terrible about doing that to him. Now: I finally decided to ask my mom to get me some help with dealing with what happened to me. (I had never told her what happened before, but she knows now.) Anyways, she made me an appointment with a Christian therapist (she doesn't want me to go to anyone who isn't a Christian) but I'm worried that I won't be able to be honest with this therapist because I know that few Christians are okay with sex outside of marriage and that's where my problem is because of the flashbacks. I don't have my own insurance and I can't tell my mom why I'd rather go to a secular therapist because she'd be really upset if she found out I've been having sex. Is it worth attempting to work with this therapist? Because I think my only other option is to just wait until I graduate and get a job with my own health insurance. Edit: Thank you, everyone. Because of various circumstances my mom had to make the appointment rather than me so I haven't had any contact with this therapist yet. I think I'll let my mom know that I only want to start with one appointment and go from there.

I say bring flowers. Probably not roses, though. If you go to a flower shop and tell them you want less formal flowers for a first date, they will probably know what flowers are best. (My sister does this type of work and she's told me it a fairly common request.)

I'm gonna feel out this therapist to start with I think. But I'm gonna keep in mind that you're probably right about my mom only being upset for a little while. I'm more concerned about what she'll think mainly cause she's always held me up as the standard to my younger siblings.

As someone who has been where your girlfriend has been, the best advice I can give is to go slow. Tell her ahead of time that she can tell you to stop - and you should always be willing to stop. Ask her if she would be more comfortable with the lights on or off. Suggest that she starts on top of you. This gives her more control and, at least for me, is less triggering. Along with letting her know that she can say stop at any time, pay attention to what her body is saying. She may dissociate or grit her teeth and just try to get through it. If either of these happen, gently get her attention and tell her you are willing to stop if she wants to. It sounds as if you do realise that she may not orgasm, which is good to know. It may take a long time before she does. She also may orgasm on the first time. As far as knowing if/when she climaxes, I can't answer those questions yet (as I said, it may be a long time before she climaxes during sex), so I'll let others answer.
I'm an ISFJ.

WRITING.TITLE: My friend is beginning to ask questions...
WRITING.TEXT: My friend recently saw cuts on my upper arm and she's been asking me why I did it. I've just been trying to play it off like it's nothing, especially since those are older. She's not fooled, but she's mostly dropped it. The thing is, I trust her, and I kind of want to tell her, but I can't. It took me three hours of sitting with my boyfriend, with him reassuring me, trying to say it to finally get it out so that he would know why I had pushed him away from me when we were only kissing. So basically, I don't think that I would actually be able to say it. DAE feel like this ever? Does anyone have an tips on how to be able to say it? I think she thinks I don't trust her anymore since I just can't tell her and I don't want her to think that. Thanks.

Thank you for the ideas. I went to a therapist for this hoping I could cope with flashbacks better. But it was a bad idea because I couldn't say most of what happened which skewed her view and she sometimes tried to pull the story out of me. She wasn't harsh or scary or bad, but it scared me even more and it makes it harder for me to open up because if a trained therapist couldn't help... My friend won't be able to help so why would I burden my friend with my problems? If that makes sense? But I think I might try your idea to call a helpline. It can't really hurt.

I thought about that.. But every time I try to write anything about it, I just end up staring at the paper trying not to cry. I'm not trying to be difficult, it just still kills me inside every time..

I obviously don't remember this, but when I was two, my family lived in Colombia and we were having a picnic with the church we were a part of. I guess I wandered off while my mom's back was turned and somehow ended up in the nearby lake. One of the guys from a nearby village was walking in the water and accidentally kicked me, and ended up pulling me out of the water. (Which apparently is amazing in itself since this man was very afraid of water spirits.) Anyways, I guess I was unconscious for a while and they almost flew me to a hospital, but I woke up before the plane was ready and the doctor there said I was fine. When my mom asked me what happened the next day, I guess I told her that a man was with me and told me to just swallow the water. And based on the amount that my mom said I peed out that night, I guess I listened. They also think I was under water for at least two maybe three minutes. Tl;dr: Almost drowned when I was two but apparently swallowed the water instead of breathing it in.

Well, I told my mom over the phone since I was in a different country. I told her beforehand that she was not allowed to ask any questions - I just needed her to make me an appointment to talk to someone when I got home. She pretty much asked if I was serious and then asked if I was okay. (To clarify, she wasn't questioning me, I think she was in shock a bit.) I'm sure she's told my dad but I haven't talked to him about it. I met my current SO after. Once I finally told him, he held me while I cried. He told me at some point, then or later, I don't remember, that he guessed based on some of my previous reactions to things. He handles things really well. Edit: It was 3 years after it happened that I told my mom because my current SO encouraged me to talk to someone about it.

Running. Unfortunately it's hard to get started with running when you're depressed. I started because my mom wanted someone to walk with. Then I got a dog who wanted to run rather than walk. Gradually I got to running and I did feel better. And then I overloaded myself with work and school and barely had time to sleep, so running was out. Don't let yourself do this. The depression hit me even harder and I could hardly handle it. But I'm slowly beginning to run again now since I have time and I can feel the difference again.
If you want to try it again, I hear that most churches offer a free programme that allows you to be born again.

Think of a balloon. As air gets blown into it, it grows. If it gets too much air, it will pop (explode almost). But if you poke a small hole near the base of the balloon where the air is entering, the air had someplace to escape without popping the balloon. For me, I felt, and sometimes still feel, like that balloon. The air is all the stress and anxiety and fears and pain I feel. In order to relieve myself before I explode like that balloon, I would cut in order to relieve the pressure before I explode. But it hurts. And it's scary sometimes.. Especially when people see and ask about it. At least it shows they care and would rather ask than blatantly stare.
When I was probably 11 or 12 I searched for Black Stallions. Since tried it again. No luck.

A picture I took at Auschwitz. It's of the fence and a sign that says says "halt". Not really sure why I chose it. I guess I just like the appeal of the halt sign. Wouldn't feel as powerful without that.

WRITING.TITLE: Orgasm but doesn't feel good?
WRITING.TEXT: Hi. I've been sexually active for eight months now with my fianc #233;. At first I couldn't orgasm at all. Not with him, not on my own. For the past 4 or 5 months, I think I've been having orgasms (or at least my body is reacting the way I've read our bodies react during an orgasm) but I feel nothing. I twitch, I guess I spasm, but I feel no pleasure and no release. In the end, it just feels like it was a lot of work for nothing since I just feel frustrated. Does anyone have any advice to make my brain feel the pleasure I'm supposed to feel? (If it makes a difference, I've orgasmed only once before, 3.5 years ago when I was raped by an ex boyfriend. I like to think that I'm mostly over it, since I don't have very many panic attacks during sex anymore, but I guess it may be a factor.) Thanks for any help or advice you can give me.

I have somewhat. We discussed the panic attacks more than anything else. I was raised in a Christian home, and the area around me was Christian so sex wasn't a common topic, but between my loving fianc #233; and time, I've been doing a lot better. He even mentioned when I was upset afterwards about having a panic attack during sex, that the time between attacks have been getting longer. It's only been recently that I've been questioning if my twitches have been orgasms since he watched me masturbate recently and said that he's almost certain he saw me orgasm but I felt nothing.
I'm not currently on any medication. Well, I take sumatriptan if I get a migraine, but I only take one pill maybe once a month.

One of my friends does. He's working on becoming a pastor and he'll write notes on what he read in his bible, how he can apply it to his life, what he can do to help others, and prayers for his family and friends. Things like that. He's one of the most legit Christians I know. He knows I don't share his beliefs but never pushes it. But having said that, I should note that the reason I know what's in those diaries is because he showed me a couple entries in which he wrote his prayers about me.

WRITING.TITLE: Including FMIL?
WRITING.TEXT: My FMIL and I get along pretty well and have no problems with each other. My dilemma is that she wants to be more involved in wedding planning. I'd like to have her be more involved as well, but I just don't know what to have her do. A little background: My FH and I live close to his family, but my family (and the wedding) is literally 1000 miles away. In all honesty, my sister is doing the majority of the work. She loves planning and weddings. She's organised and understands the little details. I'm more of big picture and so I give get an outline of what I want and she's been doing beautiful work making what I want a reality. (Yes I have the best big sister ever.) So basically, I don't know what to have my FMIL do to help involve her. I sometimes feel like I'm not even a part of the planning (though that works with my personality). How are you involving your FMIL?

That would be great... Except she doesn't really like computers. She has an iPad, but she only used it for Facebook and taking pictures. Maybe I could make it real time research by asking her to go shopping with me?

I've been telling her what ideas we're leaning towards our decisions we've made, but that's generally when she says something along the lines of wanting to do something to help out and then comments that she'll do anything I ask to help with.

That would be good. I think I might ask her to go with me to thrift stores to look for centerpieces (we have to have a really low budget) since she likes shopping at those places. Unfortunately we live in a really remote place and dress stores are pretty far away. I had my bridesmaids go as a group (since they're close to where the wedding will be and close to bridal stores) and try some dresses on recently and I think they found a dress they all like that fit my requirements. Did you ask for any input on the reception meal from anyone besides you and your (then) FH? Do you think asking her with help on that might be a viable option? (Edit to the correct meal.)
That sounds like it will be beautiful! Maybe I can ask her to maybe help with putting together centerpieces since she likes doing crafty type things.

It's good to know that sometimes it's just not easy to do (and maybe I'm not being picky on what to include her in, which I was a little worried that I was doing). I think including her in planning the events would be a lot easier if we were both closer to the venue and most of the guests.

I worked in fast food service and before you think "ew" and skip this response, I just want to say that something I learned from working in food service is that even a job as "blah" as that can be made really fun if you work with great people. Yeah. There were bad days, but I actually loved my job for the most part because I had great co-workers (usually anyways). I guess my advice is: If possible, ask friends about part time jobs they have. Do they like the work atmosphere? Try there. Is there a store/restaurant you enjoy going to because the employees seem to genuinely enjoy their jobs? It might be worth applying at those places.

I'm on mobile and I'm not very good at links, but I think this will work: http://www.mckinley.illinois.edu/units/health_ed/stress_audio/toe_to_head_txt.html I've found that this exercise works for me. It takes some time, and you'll have to modify some things if you want it to be fairly unnoticeable in public, but even modified it is helpful for me. WRITING.TITLE: 6 months...
WRITING.TEXT: That's how long I have til I get married. Six months. I desperately want to be stay clean for at least those six months, and hopefully longer. But it's so hard. It's been a year since he helped lead me to start dealing with something that happened to me four years ago on the 21st of this month. I've been struggling so much with those memories and I keep breaking my promise to myself not to give in again. I just can't stop telling myself that this time will be the last and that it will make me feel so good that I'll never have to do it again. And yet I invariably give in every time.

I've been to two different therapists in the past - one to help with the SH, and more recently the second one to help me deal with the other issue. Neither one was helpful. Besides, I moved recently and I have no clue where to find a good therapist and because it's a small town, word will get out despite HIPAA laws and I'd likely lose my job if my bosses found out.

I suppose it's possible that they weren't the right time. I was pushed into going to the first one, and I felt uncomfortable with the second one but it was the only one my mom felt comfortable with me going to. (I was still on my parents insurance.) I've tried talking to him. He encourages me to talk to him. But I can never form the words. If I get close to talking about it, I start downplaying everything like it's not really a big deal. The only times I've ever been able to talk about these things openly without holding back is when I got extremely drunk. And I never want to get to that point again. I'm honestly so thankful that he still loves me despite my problems (and he says that he knew something was wrong not long after he met me since he saw my scars). Sorry. I'm just rambling now.

If God had a reason for that to happen to me, I have no interest in worshipping or following him. When I told my atheist fianc #233; (who I met a few years later), he was nothing but comforting. I don't have a comment on how helpful or not helpful this is since I never got paid for grades. I will, however say, if you're going to pay one kid, pay the other one too. I, on the other hand, did naturally well and began to think that being naturally good at school was stupid because it meant that I was expected to do well with no reward. I agree with this. I didn't question a guy on why he didn't call me his girlfriend online or around his friends from home (didn't even introduce me to his parents as his girlfriend when they visited), but I figured that the time will come and that maybe he just thought labels were silly (my college was weird like that.) After I broke up with him for unrelated reasons, I found out that he got engaged two months before we broke up. Don't know how long they'd been dating before that. At the same time, I understand if someone doesn't want to rush into labels too fast. But labels are good for helping both parties know where they stand.

I think it's up to each couple, but if you're at the point where you think you should be exclusive, step up and say something. It's best to know where both people stand. You could realise you're looking for different things. But if a person is looking for a long term relationship, honesty is important anyways and it's actually a good place to work on establishing it.

WRITING.TITLE: How to stay motivated with a constantly changing schedule?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm fairly new here so I'm sorry if this has been answered, I did a search but didn't find anything. Anyways, I work as a sub in a mental health home care facility which means that my schedule is constantly changing. I sometimes work mornings, other times afternoon/evening, and sometimes nightshift. It's really hard to motivate myself to exercise consistently since it's not at a consistent point in my schedule on any given day. Is there anyone else on here who has a similarly changing schedule who could give me advice as to how to stay motivated or make my time of exercise more consistent?

I've been doing alright with getting workouts in on my days off. It's my lack of energy after shifts that gets me I think. I'm going to try to start scheduling in my workouts on a calendar like you suggested. Maybe if I schedule them I'll be prepared rather than thinking I can just do it later and it end up not happening.
Thanks for those tips and definitely for that link. It's helping me put things in perspective.

Wow. Now I really feel like I should be able to find time if you're able to do it while in grad school. I haven't done any grad school yet but I've heard how time consuming it is. I sometimes get weekends off. But it just depends whether or not they need me on certain days. For example: This week I have Friday and Saturday off, but I tend to use my days off to adjust to the next schedule change. Meaning I work until 7am this Thursday (but counts on the schedule as Wednesday) so they also have me scheduled to come back in at 3pm on Thursday and work til 11. So I use my days off to get rest and chores done while also readjusting my body back to working 11pm to 7am since it'll start again Sunday night. That sounds ranty, but my point is that I'm having trouble learning how/when to exercise when my body is constantly adjusting to new work schedules without stressing it too much if that makes sense. P.s. Good luck with your grad studies. :)

Well, undergrad gave me a lot of experience with sleep deprivation, so I have that in my favour. I usually sleep about four hours when I get home in the morning, and then maybe two hours before I get up to get ready. Though if I have regular day hours, I tend to get 8-9 hours of sleep straight. Originally I was going right before work, which works sometimes, but I've found that I prefer exercising in the evenings when the gym is empty (small community gym). I consider switching to a regular shift almost constantly, but the difference in pay doesn't allow it until my fianc #233;'s work picks up again in the spring. I want to ultimately lose weight to get to a healthy weight. I told the person that I used to work out with in college that I wanted to run a marathon before I turn 25. Well I'm 2.5 years from turning 25 and haven't really worked towards that goal since I graduated.

I'm not sure if it's because of him or if it really is a bad movie but I still dislike that movie. To be fair though, I haven't seen it since.

WRITING.TITLE: My bridesmaid gifts! (Partially anyways.)
WRITING.TEXT: So I'm on a small budget and I really wanted to get something useful for my ladies so I had my heart set on clutches for them all in their favourite colours. Then I saw the price of clutches so I gave the thought of them up. My fianc #233; and I had already paid a friend of mine who makes wine to make our own personal signature wine (which he's insisted on making for us at cost and refusing payment for his time/expertise) but it still took up a good portion of the budget. Anyways, the important thing is that I figured out how to make my own clutches with the help of some lovely ladies that run a quilting shop in the town I'm living in. I know they would have been made a little more evenly if i commissioned them but I think they still turned out really well and were much less expensive. I'm so excited and I need to show someone. But all the people I'd usually show I have to keep it a secret from and my fianc #233; is proud of me for getting them done and likes them, but I want to show them off a bit. So here's a picture of a few of them. I also made my flower girl one for the grown up part of her gift. Also, please forgive the tape, the glue was still setting. http://i.imgur.com/MRaOjUU.jpg
Thanks! I basically went with fabrics that fit each lady's personality.
I was actually surprised at how fast they went. Once we had the pattern, it took maybe an hour/hour and a half for each one. Also wanted to say I noticed my wedding is just one day before yours. :)

Thanks! My mom taught me how to sew and I definitely had help from the ladies at the quilt shop. They're good friends of my fianc #233; and I've been getting to know them pretty well since I moved to town.
Thanks!
Thanks. I really hope they enjoy them. They don't all dress up a lot, but I'm hoping that since they're in their favourite colours they'll find occasion to use them since they can also be causal.
Thank you! I'm glad to hear that others like them. I keep going back and forth between whether or not I think they'll like them.
Thanks!

Whenever I planned on doing something "bad" when I was little, I'd put extra pants on or stuff a small pillow in there so it wouldn't hurt as much when I got spanked afterwards. Pretty sure my parents just spanked me harder and then started diverting me from doing bad things when my butt magically got bigger.
Yeah. I wish I told my parents I wanted to switch to another school that had soccer after we moved but it was a private school and I knew we couldn't really afford it.

Maybe not nothing, but I didn't nearly as much as I should have in my Into to Psych class in college. I actually learned more in my psych class in high school that was online and a joke. Really pissed me off since I was a psych major and had very little foundation for the rest of my psych classes.
Young Ben Franklin. I've heard he was quite a stud when he was in his prime. He swam a lot and was very active. But most people think of the older out of shape guy he was when he was painted.

I worked at a taco bell where we weren't supposed to ask people to go park while their food was made - especially after dark. I've had orders of multiple taco twelve packs, other people ordering 8 empanadas, and one car ordered $50 worth of food all made with potatoes. I had one car order over $150 worth of food. It's not the order taking that takes time, it's them sitting by the window waiting for their massive order of food. Then other customers behind them get angry and take more time when they finally get to the window and demand to talk to a manager (which also slows down the food making process since they're pulled off the line.)
I had a friend who once asked me if I knew that females have five holes "down there". We were in sixth grade but I think she was just messing with me.
I use a cup and just start using it a few days earlier. It's annoying to remember to run to the bathroom to take out for sex (slows the mood a bit) but it's better than surprise tsunami.

Well fuck. My husband and I are going to be moving to Montana soon and our friend up there is planning on doing a lot of paddle boarding with us and I figured we'll try it once or twice and if we like it, buy the equipment. But now that I read your comment before getting a chance to do research...
That's great to know. I like buying used anyways but I'm glad to know that they'll probably be fairly easy to find used and that they'll probably be in good shape.

I have a scar on my hip. Never knew I had it until I started gaining weight and there was suddenly a dent in my love handle with a diameter about the size of a peach. I asked my parents about me ever having a scar there before but they don't know where it came from either. Helps me know I'm losing weight when the dent gets shallower though.

I have two jobs. I'm a Behavior Therapist and a Direct Support Professional for kids with autism. It's a great job but I would only recommend it to someone with patience or who is willing to learn it fast. Also only for people who don't gossip. You have to think about everything you say if you talking about your job with others to avoid breach on confidentiality. I make about 12,000 a year which includes what they pay for my gas. (Hoping a higher full time position will open up soon - benefits, ~33,000/year, and use my degree.) Also a cashier at Joann Fabrics. It's a pretty good job, I get yelled at by customers less than I did at Taco Bell. I'd recommend it to people who know about crafting. Make about 7,700/yr at that job.

I've been having trouble sleeping for the past two weeks. I can't fall asleep easily and when I do finally fall asleep, I have nightmares and my husband ends up having to wake me up, if I don't wake up on my own, because I'm kicking and crying. Tonight is no different. On the bright side, I got news today that a position that I want within the company I work for will be opening up soon. My supervisor told me even though she doesn't want to lose me but knows that's where i really want to be. If I manage to get it, i go from two part time jobs to one full time with benefits and a $6/hr raise (or $8 if we're talking my retail job).
You mentioned the coupon and I just wanted to mention that like all of their other coupons, it won't apply towards patterns.

Yeah. My psychology professor always explained it saying that a lot of times people don't commit suicide because depression saps the energy required to carry it out. Antidepressants give people energy before it fixes the mood/emotion problem. Hence, energy to kill oneself and little to no positive emotions to counteract the desire to be done with this life.

My mom used to always tell us growing up, "I eat my peas with honey, I've done it ask my life. It makes them sure taste funny but it keeps them on my knife." I know it's not exactly the same but your comment made me wonder if you eat peas with a knife -hence the ketchup.
I had this happen to me on the flight to my grandma's funeral. Also on the way back from my grandpa's a month later. Guess they pulled some strings for me up there.

Probably what i do now, just on a lesser scale. I work with kids with autism and love every single one of them. And I'd probably travel with my husband. Play a lot of GTA VI. Also, buy a house with a yard so I can have my dog back. My parents have been taking care of her because she's too high energy for an apartment - especially when I'm working 50 hours a week and don't have time to run with her two times a day anymore.

That last part really pissed me off. I'm pretty sure I just got really lucky, but I recently worked with older mentally disabled men and women in group homes and we were given 8 hours of sick pay every month. And it added up. You could have over 500 hours of sick pay before they'd start putting your accumulated sick pay into communal time off (for people who had long illnesses or sometimes pregnancy leave). They rarely hassled employees about using their sick leave unless he or she was an employee who was known for taking time off then being seen in the bar later that night. (which happen with one particular person pretty often.) In the US by the way.

I was showing my friend some houses that my husband and I are interested in that are in our area once we both have full time jobs instead of 2-3 part time ones and can save up for a down payment. Well I had one smaller house saved that she really loved and I said we can't really do that one because it's too small for us. I started naming the reasons we want a larger house avoiding future baby reasoning when my husband chimed in and said that we need more room if we're going to have a kid running around it. My husband doesn't talk about a future kid pretty much ever unless I bring it up. It gives me some hope that he's closer to being ready.
Poison dart shot into my left pinky toe while I'm making breakfast on the fifth Tuesday of February.

In reality, the easiest thing to love is the thing that most benefits you. A lot of times we act like we love to give to others and help others (which a lot of people do enjoy), but it's so much easier and enjoyable to receive $500 (or whatever it is that reinforces you) rather than give it to someone else.

There are 4 (or five depending on who you ask) different interpretations of Sharia law. You can ask several different people if they want Sharia law and they can all say yes with a different version of sharia law on their minds. Similar to say, Christianity and the Bible.

Going to the gym. Sure I pay to use the gym, but the money I've saved by avoiding fast food and junk food in the store just by thinking "Dude. You JUST went to the gym, you don't need that crap" is a lot higher than the monthly gym fee.

That sounds completely like me - I could have written that the post (down to turning 24 in June). My husband has to keep reminding me that we have plenty of time and that we should enjoy doing things together. And even though I agree with him, I hate waiting. But yeah, we're trying to pace ourselves so that we know for sure we're ready and aren't worried that we'll regret "losing" our freedom to come and go without worrying about a little human.
I moved to Montana recently and there are a couple roundabouts in this city.... And no one knows how to fucking use them.
Montana has an overabundance of vanity plates. I just don't understand.
Sewing and beading clutches. It's fun and relaxing for me. I might do some baking, but no matter what, I'd probably have Supernatural playing in the background.

I work at Joann Fabrics and while I was checking someone out, I asked what she was making. She told me she was making a prom dress for a student. Apparently when she was in high school a teacher made her prom dress too because her mom couldn't. She said something about thinking it was destiny for her to make a dress for her own student.

Just a lurker, but this terrifies me. My husband and I have been together for nearly three years but for the last year and a half, we've rarely used condoms - just pulled out. I can't help but wonder if something is wrong since we haven't had an "accident" yet.
I don't have any experience with a diaphragm, but you might have some luck at /r/birthcontrol

The bed frame that I'm laying on right now. I'd replace the mattress with no problem, but my husband and I built this bed frame together to celebrate our first anniversary (which was yesterday). We haven't had it long, I know, but I put a lot of sentimental value in things that we do together.
Michael if I were a boy. Apparently my dad also pushed for Mercedes at one point.

My ex told me before I broke up with him that no one will ever love me because I'm "used goods" and because of my scars. I put a good majority of those scars on myself after I couldn't handle the fact that he raped me. (I blamed myself for putting myself in the situation and then not fighting beyond telling him no.) Now I have a wonderful husband that helps me fight my depression and loves me for who I am.

I usually have the tv on in front of me just kinda think about what they're saying. Or I scheme about what I can do to move forward in my career and also earn more money so my husband and I can afford a house and a baby.

I'm someone who can spell well, but when it comes to putting words on a poster or a place where the spelling can't be easily fixed, I sometimes panic and have to look it up and ask. So could have been that type of situation.

I've been struggling a lot to see the positives about my body, but the other night my husband and I were out on a date, and I don't remember how it came up, but we were talking about my weight. He, being a history person, told me that I look wonderful, like a proper lady of the renaissance. After I sarcastically told him "yeah thanks", he told me that he actually thinks I look more like the goddess Venus - including her stomach pooch. I know I'm not actually that small, with or without my stomach pooch, but I've been looking at my body more positively since then.

Here's one that isn't really sad - yesterday I had my first orgasm with my husband and I ended up crying when it was over. Thankfully I know that's a pretty normal reaction cause I was able to reassure him it was normal. I think he thought it was because the first, and only, time I've ever had an orgasm before was when my ex raped me in college.

Good. Taking out thousands of dollars in loans isn't something that should be taken lightly. Make sure you know what you want to do and have a plan. Also, be flexible cause plans don't always work out. But seriously. Don't take out a bunch of loans for something you think you might like. It's okay to take a year off.

I've been all over the world, but my favorite place is under a tree in an arboretum about 20 miles from where I was born. It's completely private, a willow tree do you can't see in. I told my sisters that I would love to be proposed to under that tree - and my husband did without anyone telling him that's what I wanted.

We're waiting until about 16 weeks to announce publicly. We haven't hashed out all the details, but it will be on Grandparents day since our baby is the first grandchild on my side and his parents will be excited grandparents again (his mom loves being a grandma).

WRITING.TITLE: Pregnancy cravings and aversions are weird.
WRITING.TEXT: I'm 8+3 right now, and I really want to eat a simple breakfast burrito - just scrambled eggs, ranch dressing, and cheese wrapped in a wonderfully soft flour tortilla. Unfortunately, every time I smell eggs or try to put them in my mouth, my nausea kicks into high gear. And bonus on top of that - I cried because I was thinking about it on my way home from work today.
Oh no! Long flights and plane smells are bad enough when you're not pregnant, I can't imagine how bad it must have been. Uhg!

I would be so upset if I had to stop eating dark meat. And now I'm a little bit worried that I'm not going to enjoy the lamb my parents bought me when they visited. I noticed the egg aversion in myself when my mom was making breakfast for everyone and I had to walk out of the house for a little while.
Whaaaaaaat?! There's one about a half hour from my apartment but I go up that direction often enough that I could probably pick one up soon! Thanks so much!

Oh no! Personally I'm scared to try coffee even though I love it because the mom of one of the kids I work with made coffee while I was at their house and I almost lost my breakfast in their kitchen when I smelled it. So now I have a brand new bag of specialty coffee that my husband got me for my birthday, a week before my nausea kicked on. I hope your coffee loses the onion flavor really soon!

Other than the burritos, I've also been eating a ton of breakfast cereal, Cheerios are fantastic for fighting my nausea is seems, and bacon. Lots of well cooked bacon. Cause apparently all my body wants is breakfast. I'm going to look into getting some breakfast bowls.

Does guac taste more like vinegar to you than before? Cause I tried some tonight, and it just tasted like vinegar. I hope it was just the brand that my friend bought and not all guac, otherwise I'll have to be upset with you about guac.

I used to work at Joanns not too long ago and while I can't confirm that that's true, there is definitely a pattern of it happening to the point where I'm pretty sure that that is their plan. Of course, many customers I saw would still insist on buying something with their coupon even if they didn't need it so Joanns does do extra sales with those coupons. They also tend to do doorbuster sales that are exempt from the 20% coupon too. I usually ended up using my 50% and 60% off coupons on the candy/snacks and drinks since I generally bought something anyways.

I have so much burping - and I'm okay letting it out (though I try to be discrete) cause it relieves some of the nausea when the pressure is lower. The problem is more that I work with kids with autism and some of them often very loudly point out things such as "GarnetGreen is burping!" I try to use it as a teaching moment.... But not always easy.

WRITING.TITLE: I want to say thank you...
WRITING.TEXT: To whoever posted the advice about keeping a large plastic cup in the car in case of vomiting. It definitely saved me from having to announce to everyone at work that I'm pregnant because I was driving the company car and I would have had to go get a change of clothes. Thankfully I didn't have any of the kids I work with in the car - chain reactions are bad.

Yeah, I was going 70 mph down the road, there's no way I could have stopped in time. By the time I knew it was actually going to happen I only had time to grab my cup and start slowing down the car so it would be slightly less dangerous.
I never would have thought of it on my own so I'm super thankful to whoever it was that I saw suggesting it. They give me a lot of peace of mind too since I spend a lot of time in the car.

My NP started acting really worried when I told her that I was unsure if the kids I work with are all vaccinated and told me I had to find it as soon as possible and really got me worried. Well, I went to my boss and asked if all the kids are vaccinated and she asked me why I wanted to know. So I started crying (happy hormone induced tears) and told her. She's really excited for me, HR knows because they had to talk to me about how to make me comfortable since they don't know who is and isn't vaccinated since it's not required information, though they can guess. I was 7+4 when I told my boss.

I think kids just know things. One of the kiddos I work with had been suddenly really affectionate towards me (No one else) and was constantly trying to touch my stomach yesterday. This is a kid who is almost never affectionate. I work with kids with autism, so it's really surprising to me that he suddenly changed his behavior. Granted his mom had a baby somewhat recently so if he does somehow know I'm pregnant, he knows what the outcome is and I'm pretty sure he loves his little brother. I hope your three year old will be more okay with a new baby once you talk to her about getting to be a big sister.

I don't, but I'm worried that I will as soon as I tell a friend of mine, which is why she won't find out until right before everyone else finds out. I worry about it because she has made comments in the past about how she will be my child's aunt because my sisters live too far away to be aunts (cause that's how it works /s). She's also put huge pressure on my husband and I to have kids so that she can play with them, despite knowing that we weren't financially in a position to have kids, and I know for a fact that she will bitch to people if she thinks she's been slighted, but won't talk to the person about it. (Came up several times when she babysat for someone.) She also thinks she can do no wrong. So it's partially a crappy friendship, but also that she tries to take ownership of other people and their things that wants me to not have to tell her ever.

I work with a several younger kids and we solved the problem by using a label maker to put all the kids' names on the car seats with the parents' permission. Of course, a handwritten name tag would work just as well and probably be more practical for parents who don't need a label maker for anything else.

While I am from the US, my family was living across the world when 9/11 happened. We moved back to the US a year later, but it wasn't until three years after it happened that I was sitting in class at about 11 years old that I learned how big 9/11 was. Sure, my parents talked about it when it happened, my dad has pictures of us kids reading the newspaper about it, but I guess it never occurred to me that it was so life changing for people that weren't physically close to the towers. I ended up bring really embarrassed when I asked in class how everyone remember where they were for some plane crashes.

WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone else have that one annoying friend?
WRITING.TEXT: Fair warning: this is going to be a bit of a rant. So I'm 13+3. We announced about a week ago and told this particular friend about a day in advance. Since then I have seen her twice and both times she has touched my stomach. The first time I just stepped back cause it was so unexpected. The second time, before it even happened, I kept making comments about how everything is still just fat cause the uterus hasn't risen above the pelvic bone yet and yet when we were leaving, she touched me again and said "goodnight new friend". Thankfully I already had my husband on board with how much I hate it and he said something about how awkward it is to just be touching my fat. (The original plan was that he keep himself between us so if she goes to touch that he move in front so she ends up getting his stomach but we were in a car so that didn't work.) But besides the touching thing, she has nicknamed our baby. She nicknamed him/her Barbara. I told her no immediately, but she hasn't stopped. So we just keep referring to the baby as Beowulf and ignoring her every time she says Barbara. She also insists that the baby has to be a girl (cause we can decide that you know) despite knowing that husband and I are hoping for/think it's a boy. She's also mad at us because we're refusing to tell anyone, including her, the names we have picked out. She also asked to be an honorary aunt since my sisters aren't living anywhere close (though my family had been looking to move anyways and are talking about moving closer to me). But at least she asked cause before she knew I was pregnant she TOLD me that she was going to be any future babies' aunt cause my sisters were too far away to really be aunts. We're honestly just hoping at this point that she'll get a job in another state (she's actively looking right now) because she really can be a great friend - but we've realised that from afar is best. Sorry about the rant, I just needed to vent to someone else because I'm sure my husband is tired of hearing about it.

I don't understand why people feel the need to butt in on baby name conversations like that - though I am happy for you that it at least helped you realise that Dustin had a potential nickname that you didn't like. And I know that a direct approach to get is really the best, but she always seems really hurt whenever I'm direct about things she's done that bother me and she tries to play it like I'm at fault. Also a bit worried that the hormones will make me permanently end this friendship even though I do like her, just more from a distance.

Yeah, it'd be nice if she would at least all so I could tell her that once it's actually a baby there, she can touch when I give her the okay. And I have previously told my husband that I'm done with her and I can't stand her, but he's my voice of reason that usually reminds me of the reasons that we are friends and why it'd be better to just phase out the friendship when she moves rather than just end it. (That sounds awful but I've seen what happens when people cut her out of their lives - she tells everyone she knows how awful that person is and how they were never a good friend and will tell any secrets they told her.)

Yeah, I mentioned in another response that she's the type of person who will tell everyone how awful you are and any secrets you've ever told her will no longer be secrets if you cut her out of your life. I stopped telling her anything that I wouldn't want people knowing about me the first time I realised that, but she still knows a lot. And yeah, I suppose I could use the honorary aunt thing to try to put her behavior on extinction. I think I'm going to give that a try if she continues to ignore when I tell her to stop.

Oh goodness. I really hope that when I'm more direct with her next time that she won't think I don't mean her. And yeah, I get what you're saying about it being note peaceful without them being there and over excited. I'm pretty sure I'm the first pregnant person my friend has ever had experience bring close to. So I'm also trying to remind myself that her only social script to play on is from movies - where all anyone every talks about is the baby and everyone touches the bump and forgets that the mother is still a human being. So I kinda wonder if that's why it's so hard to achieve a balance unless they've already had a lot of experience around pregnant women.

You do have a point as far as why did we announce. Well, I moved a lot as a kid and as an adult, but I still have friendships that while it would be weird to call/text out of the blue to let them know, we all enjoy keeping up with each other on Facebook - hence announcing. Also cause relatives that I don't want to talk to can find out on there. Hell, I'll talk about gender, no biggie, but I refuse to tell her names because I know too many people who have had people pissed at them for "stealing" names or have had people criticise the name to the point where the parents hate it even though they loved it for a long time before that. And I expect nothing from her when it comes to baby care or gifts. For fucks sake - I plan on being alone with my baby and my husband for as long as I can keep people away (except my immediate family cause they stay out from under my feet and don't expect me to wait on them hand and foot like most people.) And I've been responding to other people on here with the reason she's not already out of my life... So yeah.

True... I should probably also mention that we live literally about 300 feet from her... Which is a lot of the reason we want her to just find another job and move. Of course, my husband and I are looking to buy a house which will help. The worst part is, I really do enjoy spending time with her sometimes, it's just that I need so much time to prepare myself and then time to decompress after because I'm always on my guard around her even when we're just hanging out.

I get the smoking feeling. Granted, I only quit a year ago and since it was a stress relief for me, it makes sense that the craving is coming back, but I haven't had this strong a craving since the day I quit cold turkey.

I think coins is perfect. You don't even need a large amount constantly available (unless you want to make a large platform to manipulate into levitating you). As weaponry, you can easily choke someone with a single coin, or with enough speed and spin, I believe you could use them to slice skin.
Yeah, and you gotta love it in Montana. We have huge fires AND we'll get to deal with shitty winter that seems to never end.

Haha. I guess we better start hoping for winter to start soon before the whole state is gone. I mean, fuck, one of the fires doubled in size overnight this weekend (50,000 acres to over 100,000 acres).

Thanks. And yeah, I'm pretty lucky to live in a city that's still pretty safe. Just dealing with a lot of smoke, but I'd rather have smoke than fire. And thankfully our senator secured 3.3 million in grants this week or last to put towards fighting the fires. It's great seeing our communities coming together to support our firefighters and displaced people who have been evacuated.

I work with kids on the autism spectrum. Apparently some of them find comfort in touching one of my scars that sticks up a lot. I'll be talking to them when they're upset and they'll hold my arm and start running their fingers over it. Another kid, when he's nervous talking to people, will do the same thing. Most of my scars on my arms have faded now, but I still have that one and a similar one on the other arm that are still really obvious and likely always will be since I was in an especially bad place with those.

It's said a lot that there really is no good time to have a baby. Most people can always be more financially stable, their careers can always be further along etc. I decided I was ready long before my husband was mostly because I realised that I was putting off the decision to have kids based on things that weren't happening. I had wanted to get my masters first, but I was waiting until I was at my job long enough to ask them to help (since they do that sometimes) and I recently learned that they're going through a period of change and they're unlikely to do any assistance for a while. There were other things too, but this is getting long. My point is, I was ready when my husband became emotionally ready to have a kid because I realised that there is a lot outside of my control and if I waited until everything seemed to be ready - I would probably still have several years of waiting ahead of me where I wasn't really doing much to step towards my goals (except saving). The final reason I decided I was ready was because I realised that I can still be a kick ass mom while continuing to pursue my goals when the time is right to pursue them further.

If we have a girl we're going to name her Sabriel Rhea. Sabriel is from the first book (of the same name) that my husband introduced me to and we both love that book. Rhea is a variation of my grandpa's name, Raymond, who passed away a little over a year ago. If we have a boy, he will be named Ashton Briar. No particular reason other than my husband loves the name and wants to call him Ash. Our last name starts with C, so having the initials ABC was a factor in helping my husband find the name. Previous male choices included Sebastian, Lucius, Jude, and William.
My husband and I both pronounce it say-briel. I have to say, the pronunciation thing is my biggest worry despite how much I love the name.

WRITING.TITLE: I have to throw in my own husband brag...
WRITING.TEXT: Today is the 80th anniversary of The Hobbit... And he's reading it out loud to me. I've always loved being read to and today I've been so miserable with getting sick at work (cause morning sickness doesn't always end at 12 weeks apparently) that I think he wanted to do whatever he can to make me feel better. He also watched The Rings of Ahketan (my favorite Doctor Who episode) with me while we ate supper. P.S. His dad called so he's busy talking to him right now - I'm not ignoring him reading.
Awee. And hey, that means that there's more still to read to the baby. Wonder if him reading would comfort and quiet your baby since it would be something familiar.

I was sucking/chewing on ginger at first, but I got so sick of the taste after about six weeks of it. But it has been a while. Maybe I'll try it again today and see if it'll get me through work. And since I passed the second trimester mark I've been hearing a lot about it ending at 17, 20, or 24 weeks. I've already hit 17, so I'm going my magic number is 20, if not earlier.

Yup. It's funny, my sisters are much more geeky than I am, but I'm pretty sure they're the ones that made me love so many geeky things, and then I fell in love with a man who also loves the same (mostly) geeky things. Oh boy. I'm hoping it'll go away before my next appointment, the anatomy scan! and check up, but if not, I'll probably ask for something. I'm just afraid it'll make me sleepy since I already tried the unisom/b6 combo and found it made me too tired at work. Plus I'm already planning on asking for something to help with the heartburn since that seems to wake me up more than needing to pee plus I'm constantly carrying tums with me everywhere. I hope your sickness goes away soon!

I work with kids with developmental disabilities... Ever since getting pregnant I've been so exhausted and I'm terrified that I'm going to fall asleep at work, especially when the kid is supposed to be working independently so I'm pretty much just sitting there trying to stay awake and making sure they stay on task.
Currently living in beautiful western Montana. :)

My biggest fear is not having the job when I return. The maternity pay doesn't matter as much since my company doesn't pay me anything anyways, but according to policy, will pay in full my vacation I have built up and a lot of my sick time off i quit. Though honestly it's not a lot anyways since I don't accrue it as fast as actual full time employees.

Your post was one of the ones I was thinking about, but couldn't find, when I made this post. My biggest worry is that as soon as I mention I'm pregnant, either in the interview or after if I decide to wait, that they'll find another reason to not hire me, or they'll just fire me because they'd be within their rights in my state to fire without a cause/without having to disclose a reason. Other worry is that while I'm applying for a position that you don't want a big turnover as it can be detrimental to the clients, it's not a job that is hard to find people to do the job, whether they're good or not you often can't know until they've been there for some time, but they wouldn't necessarily think if they don't hire me they won't find someone else for a long time so I'm not sure how willing they'd be to work with me. But I think I am going to apply. I'm just going to have to tell them I won't quit my other job until I have an offer and I'm still going to give them a two weeks notice.

Yeah. My initial thought is to disclose during the interview, if I would get one, just because if they're not willing to work with me on it, I'm not sure I'd even really want to work with them. I have found that working in human services, people tend to be much more open to working with you. I guess I have to keep reminding myself that I do still have a job, it's just not the job that I ever thought would be permanent and I'm a person afraid of getting stuck in a place I don't want to be so I'm always looking for ways to keep moving towards what I want.

My sister has been going through this for a few years now. She's adopted so she's a lot younger than me so it's easier for me to see. I've tried to tell her several times when she brings up things that they've done that they're cruel and don't want her. I've tried to tell her it's not a bad thing to not be accepted into a group of cruel people. The problem is that she also tries really hard to be cool and refuses to try to be friends with anyone who isn't cool. I know that they had her convinced that she had to bring all the team snacks to games, and she tried to have them all be handmade before my mom caught on and stopped it. But before she was brought into our family, it was basically drilled into her head by her adopted sisters and their movies that you have to be popular or you're worthless.

I told my husband that I definitely felt the baby move tonight (he's also been denying that that's what I've been feeling), and he jokingly told me that it's "not fair" because he's supposed to be the first one to feel the baby move. *eyeroll* it's not like I told him that I grabbed someone else's had to feel it from the outside before he's had a chance to try.
Of course! Especially if one of the babies is really shy and determined to hide... Right?! :)

Well, my middle of the night brain certainly agrees that it's possible. My family has twins in it too: my great uncles were twins, my second cousins were twins, but it seems that it didn't get passed through my mom's grandma. I know my dad's side is less relevant but there are so many twins on that side it's crazy. I can't imagine having so many twins around me right now. D:

Hahaha. I told my husband now that he's awake, and he's insisting that I'm not big enough to have twins. Scumbag brain is saying... But does he really know what size a woman is "supposed" to be this far along? His sisters have both been pregnant but neither we're living with him at the time and I'm pretty sure that they were already larger than I was when we conceived - so not sure the comparison is relevant. That was a long not super relevant way of saying that husbands can be wrong.... Right? :)
Some jewelry stores will do this with 6 months 0% interest. My friend works in a jewelry store and keeps trying to convince me to buy since she says my credit will be good enough to qualify.
Nah. She just works on commission and really wants my money.

I see your point, but she's really not pushy. It mostly comes up around holidays and anniversaries when a lot of people buy jewelry. Also because she knows my husband wants to get me matching earrings for the pearl necklace he got me on our wedding day.

I believe it. I've been secretly hoping for twins since my husband and I decided that we're only doing pregnancy once - any other future children will be adopted... But I worry that our finances won't allow that to happen for many years and I want our kid to have a sibling somewhat close in age.

Hahaha. I mean, theoretically my niece and nephew might need adopting soon, so that's kind of the same? They'd only be about 2.5/4 years older than my baby... Luckily my friend is also pregnant so there will be another child close in age around, even if he/she isn't a sibling.

My OB has a sign in their bathroom that says that if you feel unsafe, you can use their phone to call a crisis center or women's shelter. I would think any doctor would be willing to allow women to use their phone for this, plus nothing suspicious about gong to the doctor when you're pregnant.

This is really helpful for the nausea, but be aware that the unisom is a sleeping pill. I had to give up on using it because I work with kids and drive them a lot and it wasn't safe, even when only using half a pill.

Uhg. I've complained to my husband about this a lot lately. We're hoping that with savings I will be able to take 8 weeks of leave since, despite working in early childhood development, I get no paid leave other than vacation and sick pay. But I was recently discussing my plans briefly with my supervisor and a kid's parent regarding how long I'll take off so they can plan on a sub or something for that time, and I mentioned that I probably won't take the whole 3 months of FMLA. They both told me that I really should take the whole time because I need it to be with my baby and recover. I just wanted to tell them that financially, that's impossible unless the company decides to pay my leave, but that would have been unprofessional so I just said we'll see.

Awee. :/ I actually have the opposite problem - taco bell is close, and while I crave it at times, what I really want is Chipotle but the closest one is two hours away and I've heard terrible things about that particular store. :/

WRITING.TITLE: I held a baby today...
WRITING.TEXT: And I realised that I have no fucking clue what to do with a baby when they're still little. And he's about four months old. And a big baby for his age. Most of my experience with babies is from about 8 months on. I'm still super excited, don't get me wrong, but as soon as I was holding him, I began second guessing how I'm supposed to behave around a baby. Good thing my mom is going to come help us out for the first month or so.

I sure hope you're right. I know that a lot of it will be easier when I've had time with my boy and understand him, but I tend to second guess when it comes to the welfare of others on whether or not I'm doing right.

Right? The youngest I've ever held was 6 weeks old and I only held her because my friends all noticed that I hadn't held her and basically forced me to hold her. Which is fine, I've gotten more comfortable with kids since then... But they look so fragile!

Thanks. :) I don't think my husband has held a baby since he was 15 with his nephew. Except the time I forced him to hold his niece when she was 10 months. His mom thought it was funny that I made him (she knew I had baby rabies before I'd even admit it to myself). But I do have a great support system - I just wish the majority of it didn't live 1000-2000 miles away.

Ours does, but last time I looked at the times, they were offered at 5:30- which is generally when I get off work and I don't get back to town until 6/6:30. I should look again. I haven't looked since I was first offered a flyer about 15 weeks ago.

Hahah. I sure hope that my fear goes away. I love babies, I'm terrified of being one of two people actively keeping him alive. Of course, I also used to be petrified of all kids - and now I work with kids with autism and love every single one of them - even though I'm supposed to be somewhat detached. Oops. :) I probably just need the exposure. I was the second youngest and my sister is only two years younger so I don't remember her being little and I'm not around my niece and nephews enough (and they're older anyways.)

I'm so glad to hear that it's also normal to not take to it quite right away - that means that if I don't, it won't be the first time and the nurses will likely know to just push me. Someone was telling me yesterday that with her first, she got upset when an experienced mom was burping her baby cause she didn't know that the baby was okay getting very firm pats.
This us what I thought today when I held my co-worker's baby!
And yet we're still constantly finding Canadian pennies in the US.

I'm glad I'm not the only one that thought it was a dancing person - though my mind refused to make sense of the antler part. I finally sucked it up and asked a friend why so many people had weird dancing stickers on their trucks - and of course he laughed before he explained.

I was talking to a friend and I mentioned something I had seen on the news that I figured she'd find really interesting. She was looking at her phone (as usual) and when I finished telling her about it, she said "oh, cool" and kept looking at her phone. Five minutes later, she said "Hey! Have you seen [same thing] in the news?" I called her out on it, but it hasn't changed the fact that she never listens to anything I have to say unless it's something she asked me about.

I think the mother/father thing used to be really common among religious (?) older generations. I don't really know how common, or why, I just remember asking my mom about it once because I was so confused when watching Disney's Robin Hood and the church mice were calling each other mother and father when they clearly couldn't both be each other's parent.

Like you said, kid-by-kid basis, but sometimes kids just like being talked about, even if they're not trying to be cute. Talking about them within earshot can make them recognize that they have your attention, and then they ramp their behavior because they know you're watching and they want to see how far they can go before you react how they want. That's where planned ignoring comes into play - but that's generally best for environments when you have basically total control (your house vs public areas).

My mom used to have us eat at least as many veggietales as our age - if we were eating green beans for supper and were nine years old, we had to eat at least nine green beans. We could always have more, but we had to at least that many. She did sometimes have two types of veggies at a meal, but then we could choose one or the other.

I love Motherhood maternity jeans. They're expensive unless you get sales, but they're comfortable and I can get them long enough for me (5'9"). I do agree with the person who said try them on in store if possible. Get a pair or two to hold you over until they have a really good sale. My only problem with them so far is that they do get stretched out easily but a wash will get them back to normal.

Uhg. It's so awful. My mom keeps telling me that she doesn't know why I'm so sick - none of the other women in the family had "morning" sickness for 20 weeks straight (or really more than three weeks). Gee thanks, mom. Good to know that I have no one to ask advice from in the family. The joy and beauty of pregnancy everyone talks about is bullshit. Maybe I'll feel differently once I get through the next 17 weeks.

I have a friend, who was fielding a lot of similar questions from me, tell me that as far as warmers for wipes and bottles, it's better to get the baby used to what will be normalized. If the baby won't have constant access to warm wipes, get him/her used to it early on instead of when you're out and about. And she said that with her second kid - he basically drinks milk almost straight from the fridge, or sometimes only room temp, since they didn't see the need for him to have all his bottles warmed and he's going to have to drink cold milk eventually anyways (although she did mention that some babies have more reflux problems with cold milk early on). It helped me feel less anxious as a FTM about what I need for baby since some of the things aren't hard rules must haves - and some of these things are modern conveniences that aren't absolutely required. She also said that all babies are different, so I'll probably still end up with things that I thought were necessary, but baby hates - like some kids hate rockers, while others love them.

I love the smell. I haven't smoked in a few years, but damn, being pregnant makes me want to smoke just because the smell is so familiar and comforting (i smoked for stress relief). I have to focus on not taking deep breaths every time I pass someone smoking because I love the smell so much.

I was confused for a while on the spelling of "a lot" and "no one" because my teacher put them in a list of spelling words on a test just to see where everyone was with their spelling. Up until that point, I had never heard of people putting two words as one answer on a spelling test. I still think it shouldn't have been done that way.

I quit smoking over two years ago, and yet I keep desperately wanting to smoke since I got pregnant. I miss the smell, I miss the taste, and it's a damn good thing that I refuse to smoke while pregnant because I don't want to start smoking again ever. But I agree, I can't tell anyone because I feel like no one would understand.
I have muffins in the oven and I'm waiting for them to be done. I've been wanting muffins for weeks but haven't been able to stomach them.

I really needed to read this. I've been terrified that I won't be able to breastfeed or that if I'm able to force myself to do it, that I would start to resent my son or not bond through it if I would start to disassociate during that time. My husband also hates that he has to leave my breasts alone a lot of the time - though he's wonderful about respecting that boundary. So thank you for posting this. It made me cry, but also gave me some peace of mind.

I think the tendency for depression was probably there to begin with - but having money makes it easier to give in to it because you're not forced to work and get out of the house most days. It's why I've told my husband that even if we get to the point where we can afford for me to be a stay at home mom, that I need to at least have a part time job - even if I'm not making any meaningful income after child care for that time. But I agree, having some more money would help reduce stress and maybe help with some of the mental heaviness.

Honestly, I was afraid of ruining my carefully built image. If I had succeeded that night, it's likely that my secret of being raped by my boyfriend would have gotten out along with the fact that I hadn't been handling it well for the previous couple of months despite the fact that I was a good college freshman and it looked like I had pretty much everything going for me. Looking back I realise that it was all that self imposed pressure that led me to try that night. And to be fair, I don't know why I pulled the needle out (survival instincts maybe) but the reason above is why I didn't try again - not because I got better. I began repressing the memories every time they came up, and it led to a pretty big break down my senior year in front of the man (who later became my husband) when I tried to have consensual sex with him. Now he's the reason I will never try again. He's helped me face what happened to me and process it. And if I had succeeded that night 7 years ago? I wouldn't be looking forward to holding our son in my arms in just a few more months.

I had a professor that wrote the book and made it mandatory - but he was also the leading expert on the subject and had us take a vote on which charity all the proceeds he got would go to. The book was also only $20 brand new.

My FIL was helping us move last week and needed pair of scissors. Thankfully his hands were full and he asked my husband to grab my sewing scissors that I left out (no kids yet) and my husband told him no, but he'll go look for another pair. So proud of my husband. :) Also, my FIL was gracious enough to wait after my husband told him they were sewing scissors - his mom was a quilter.

My wedding cake tasted really good. Of course, I insisted on having buttercream frosting instead of fondant. I think it's the fondant that makes wedding cakes taste nasty. I didn't want an elaborately decorated cake which is probably why it was possible - but it was still beautiful. Quick edit: I also didn't spend a ton on the cake - think it came out to a dollar a slice. Most places in my area wanted 3-4 dollars a slice, but luckily I knew someone who did wedding cakes for fun on the side.

Not gonna lie, it cracks me up watching people who see me on a regular basis glance at my obviously growing stomach but not say anything. I'm pretty sure that at this point it's pretty obvious (but Idk, the only people who have the baby bump are people who know for sure) but people around me have been great about not saying anything.

My husband and I just bought a house. Came with an old set of Maytag washer and dryer. I was so excited! We donated our set we had at our apartment because while they worked, we bought them used and didn't know how long they would continue to last. But we know these will last for a long time. My mom was jealous - but happy for us. :)

I decided to shave the other day since I was taking a bath anyways... It was terrible. I'm only 27 weeks but I'm on the bigger side anyways so I was having trouble seeing what I was doing but I was proud of myself for getting it done... Until a few hours later when I realised I have large strips of unshaved areas on both legs. Only 13 more weeks till I'll consider trying again.

I don't know about other bread companies, but the one my husband works for rotates their brand bread out of grocery stores a week before the due date to the discount store - they bake the store bread too, but unless you really pay attention to the date, you're probably eating older bread with store brand. Best solution - find out if the brand has a discount store. Only place I'll ever buy bread. Often have lower prices than store brand as well as deal days.

I get why you're being downvoted, but honestly, I can see where you're coming from. I work with kids with autism and while I'd never wish a single one of them harm or death, I see the stress that the parents of the more affected kids go through. I see them struggle to connect to their child, to keep from yelling at their kid when the kid just has a really bad day. I've seen parents cry when, after months of working on a program over and over and over with them, the kid finally gets it. I've seen a mom struggle with the fact that her child shows more affection to myself than her (simply due to the amount of time I put into working on him being more comfortable with me touching his shoulder to get his attention). Anyone who denies that those parents are going through a much more difficult time and have a harder road ahead of them than many of the parents of typically developing children is doing both them and their children harm and is a disgrace. Everyone needs and deserves compassion and understanding.

WRITING.TITLE: TIC because I realised that I'll be a mom on mother's day.
WRITING.TEXT: I know mother's day is a ways off, but someone on Facebook mentioned it, and I started crying because I'll be holding my own son when the next mother's day arrived.

I have a friend that keeps asking me if I'm sure it's not twins because she really wants twins... Like fuck off, woman. Even if I was having twins, (definitely not unless, like you said, the other baby is a hide and seek champ) they wouldn't be yours! I'm still trying to figure out how to avoid her during my two months of maternity leave since she keeps telling me how excited she is to play with my baby....

My mom was looking at onesies online with my little sister (14) while on the phone with me and I heard my sister get excited and say that she really liked that one. Apparently they had come across one that said something like "bachelor of the year". Thankfully I'd had this conversation with my mom, who agrees, and she just told my sister that I didn't want any onesies like that since my son will be a baby that doesn't need to be worrying about dating or marriage yet. I've been very vocal about not wanting onesies like that any time anyone mentions buying clothes for my baby.
