Not quite the same, but I'm still really annoyed that my company decided to start fully paying for STD starting this year. We didn't have the option at all last year unless we went outside the company - just LTD. If they had it last year, I would be getting paid my full pay for 13 weeks to be gone, but no, I'm not eligible for it because I was pregnant for more than three months before it started.

I'm pretty sure my mom felt this pressure too, though more from her siblings than her friends. She used to put a lot of pressure on my older sister to get married, which was pretty dumb since my sister wants to get married but she isn't going to settle for just anyone to make my mom happy. Then I got married (the fourth child) and suddenly my mom puts less pressure on my sister to go find a man (though I know she does still pressure her some). And their relationship has improved a lot. I can't really say I blame my mom - her siblings are competitive, but in a really petty kind of way. And I know my mom hates it, but I also am pretty sure that she's secretly proud that even though she was the last one to have a kid get married, she's also only the second to get a grandchild - the first grandson.

My husband and I used mostly the pull out method for 2.5 years before deciding to try.. we started trying before we were actually hoping to get pregnant because we figured we couldn't possibly just be that good... yeah. First shot.
If you're near a target, mine recently had some wraps on clearance. Worth a shot depending on how the good the used market is near you.

I assume that by not being near the med room, meds weren't the innocent woman's responsibility those days. There's also a possibility the guilty person forged the innocent woman's initials to make look like did all the meds except one - but she can't initial off not near the room.

Nausea. I had nausea so early (3-4ish days after conception according to the due date I was given by the doctor) that people were constantly telling me it couldn't possibly have been caused by the pregnancy. The test didn't show positive for another week (I also waited cause I didn't want to waste another test). Oh, and I went fishing for work on a really windy day two days after the nausea started. So that was fun.
How do you like your Vicks humidifier? We registered for one on my MIL's advice but for once I didn't do a ton of review checks.

I have a mole down below and I like to check on it every once in awhile just to make sure it's staying small/not going to become a problem. My husband started laughing when he walked into the bathroom while I was holding a mirror and looking at my mole. And then finally said that he didn't realise that I can't see anything down there without help.

...I didn't realise that not having a private room was a possibility during/after giving birth. I just kind of assumed that all hospitals just had smaller private rooms for after birth (which my hospital has) and my view was never challenged. Good to know.

My husband and I have a similar plan, 20% after $300, and I thought it was a great plan... but his company also pays for the whole family plan which I'm sure makes a difference - especially since if we went with my company's plan, we'd be paying about $600/month for a $3000 deductible. Plus more per month once we'd add baby.

Not sure how busty you are, but I found some fantastic zip up sports bras at target (c9 brand if I remember correctly) that separate the boobs and are supportive with no wire. Caveat - if you're too busty (as I am for that bra especially with pregnancy boobs, just doesn't bother me) they will squish together. Anyways, worth a try.

Holy shit. I want her insurance too. Damn. But that is true - though I've found that it doesn't seem to matter what line of work you're in, if the company can save money without losing too many good workers, they'll do it. I don't know how hospitals work, but do you get any sort of discount for being an employee with insurance helping pay towards the discounted price?

As a history major, I was given a handout like this in one of my classes (more of a list form though). Soon after I got engaged my sister was helping me pack to move in with my now husband, and we found the handout. My sister asked if she could embroider it as a wedding gift. Of course i said yes. And that's the story of how my husband and I have these 1950's housewife rules prominently displayed in our house. People who know us well think it's hilarious, and those that don't seem a little uncomfortable when they see it.

My husband acted pretty similarly until about 30ish weeks when he could consistently feel movement from the outside as well as seeing my body very obviously changing. Going to a labor class helped too. Before he didn't really feel much connection and baby tended to stop moving when he touched my belly so he wouldn't try much. But i kept putting his hand back. I'm pretty sure that the biggest factor in connecting him to the pregnancy was when he was reading something to me and I started laughing because baby kept rolling - but every time he stopped reading to look, baby stopped. So I told him to keep talking next time he looked, and sure enough, baby kept rolling to his voice. Just keep gently pushing your SO to be involved here and there. He'll get there. Your baby will start to respond to him too, and it'll start to click with him.

Leave now and you'll have a chance to have a normal sex life with your husband later instead of having to decide if you're okay to have sex now or not every single time. And you'll save yourself the deep feeling of guilt every time you have to real your husband to stop in the middle because you suddenly can't handle it.

As a person who majored in history, I heartily disagree. I realise that unless you're going to read old documents or a grandparent's letter, the ability to read/write cursive seems useless, but that skill was so valuable to me when researching documents as primary sources. And if we stop teaching that skill, how many people are going to shy away from using primary sources rather than go through the trouble of learning how to read them? That, and like I mentioned, I appreciate being able to read letters my grandparents wrote to me, especially now that they've passed away.

I'm no expert on Medicaid, but I believe that since you aren't married and she doesn't yet have an income (and her insurance through her parents should be deemed inadequate for pregnancy) she should be eligible for Medicaid. Which I also believe will backdate to cover expenses related to the pregnancy - but of course still best to apply early. I have a friend currently getting prenatal care through Medicaid and just wanted to say that she is getting equal care as myself. We go to the same OB practice and are likely going to deliver in the same hospital. Also, consider going to a woman's health clinic and see if they have any information to help get good care as soon as possible. They might know places that will give prenatal care on a sliding scale.

WRITING.TITLE: When my husband is getting ready for work at 3am and asks me why I'm not sleeping.

WRITING.TEXT: Same here! He's constantly scheduling dance parties for the middle of the night. He's starting to run out of room by now, but that doesn't seem to stop him.

I'm just going to say that I really appreciate that Montana starts clearing the roads asap (except sometimes on weekends). The roads still aren't great while the snow is falling, but it's great that they get started on it so that by the time it does get to where it would have been 3-4", the roads are still easily passable. But we also tend to get 6-12+ inches at a time so it's probably the only real way to keep a handle on all the snow.

I just had my son yesterday afternoon (can't sleep cause adrenalin and cause he's so beautiful I can't stop looking over at him). But in the 13 hours since his birth, I have already received so many rewards from my little boy. His eyes on me while he eats, his response to my and my husband's voices, the way he calms down when I sing to him even when he's cold but is getting his diaper changed, and his little mewling sounds he makes when he sleeps. I know I'm just beginning, but I can't understand how there are parents out there who don't appreciate the little miracles they gave life to.

Yup. I had one supervisor ask me where my coat was because it was 15 degrees out, and my other supervisor (who just had a kid) said, "She's pregnant. She's probably really hot" as I attempted to convince the kid I was working with that it was too cold for him to not wear a coat.

My husband loves his. It's an '03 and sure, it has some problems, but not really anything more than what you'd expect from any car that age. Granted, it's also his pride and joy so he does its maintenance and constantly is making sure its in great condition - then pushes it to its limits when driving it. It's also manual. Don't know if that makes a difference.

Sorry, lady stepping in here. Are you in the US? If so, get your wife on Medicaid immediately. They'll insure the rest of the pregnancy and save you a lot of money and stress over the money. Might have to change doctors and she might have to compromise on some parts of her ideal birth plan, but it's worth it.
Yeah, never do this in Montana. Guaranteed you will be t-boned within 1-2 months. Seems like everyone here runs reds trying to beat them.

I didn't take a single math course in college. Granted, it was because I got college credit for my high school math course - which would have been easy enough to fake my way through for credit if I hadn't been good at math.

Our realtor was also amazing - took everything we were looking for into account, showed us properties that were well below our budget that fit our requirements, spent several evenings showing us houses, and even helped us with knowing which schools were best and giving her experience with the schools. And that's why when my parents decided to move to the area, we sent them (and their 125k higher budget) straight to her. It's more profitable long term for a realtor to do a good job.

You're right. In the North, the goal was to reunite the North and South. The South seceded in the first place over state's rights - they wanted states to have more say in laws than the federal government had. The driving force behind wanting states to have more say was mainly the issue of slavery. So yes, it was somewhat about slavery, but not completely. Lincoln said that if he could reunite the states without freeing a single slave, he'd do it. It's complicated. Also, there are many places in the South that refer to the American Civil War as the War of Northern Aggression - referring more to their view that the North was forcing their beliefs on a group of states that wanted to leave peacefully.

This is also my mindset. Some of my siblings constantly made us late for things, and I think it's my way of compensating for it. Though I'm very glad for it now that I have a baby cause one a baby is involved, all kinds of time buffers are needed to make sure you get out the door even remotely on time. But anyways, maybe your dad always being late instilled your need for buffers?

I briefly worked at the McKinley Museum in Canton which displayed several of the letters written to this man (Sam Stone) who went by the pseudonym B. Virdot. The man compiling the letters before they were displayed showed them to me and told me that the man's grandson figured out that B. Virdot was a play on Stone's daughters' names (I think it was two girls, it's been a couple years). There's something really heartbreaking and yet uplifting (from the hope) when reading those letters.

I stopped swaddling my son four nights ago (he's three months today). I had been swaddling him with his arms free for about a week (and off and on for the past month) since he would use them to completely break free of his blanket if they were swaddled inside. Then I did two nights of arms and legs free from the swaddle (basically a blanket wrapped fairly tight around his middle). He was still sleeping well so I decided to not swaddle him at all and so far, all four nights he's slept 8-9 hours straight still.
Yes. He's been sleeping in his own room since he was 11 weeks old. He's 13 weeks now.

When I first moved him to his own room, he went from 8/9 hours straight a night to waking up every 4/5 hours. That lasted 2 nights and he was back to regular sleeping. When we stopped swaddling him, his sleeping wasn't affected at all as far as I know since if he did wake up, he wasn't upset because he didn't wake me up.

I don't know the details, but my little sister was adopted from overseas when she was around 2 or 3. They wanted her for a companion for their biological daughter. I don't how she was at that age, but she's currently very bullheaded and doesn't like to do things other people's ways. They ended up sticking her in the foster care system because she wasn't a good match for their daughter. And when I say companion, I mean companion. They didn't want another daughter. They wanted another kid that would occupy their daughter's time that would be compliant and, I'm assuming, so grateful for being adopted from an orphanage that she would do anything that family asked of her with no troubles or complaints.

I'm not sure because it's often hard to tell cost when you're on the outside only considering it instead of actively working towards adoption, but I'm pretty sure the 40k adoptions are the ones for infants from private companies that match you with a mother that has an unwanted pregnancy. The cost goes for the mother's healthcare (i think), lawyers, and of course for the people that helped find the pregnant mother for you. Adoption from the foster care system is much cheaper - Mostly paying for the paperwork to be filed and the significantly cheaper lawyer to oversee the paperwork. They're more motivated to get the kids adopted because they're more difficult to adopt out of foster care once they're past a certain age or if they're part of a sibling group.

Yeah. They adopted her when she was about 11. My aunt and uncle (who help parents with adoption) approached my parents about adopting her because the foster home she was in was trying to get rid of her (like I said, she's bullheaded) and they didn't want to see her get bounced to another foster home.
If I remember correctly (I was only 8 or so) my dad would bread it lightly and grill it anytime he was able to get croc. It was amazing.

I work as a behavior technician with kids with autism and I say that it will definitely get harder before it gets easier. But that's why you have to listen to the behavior therapist. Even if you would send him to a day program and he did great there, there's no guarantee that he'll also do great at home if bad habits continue to get reinforced at home. I've seen it several times where a kid's parents are at their wits ends because they give into the kid every time so any time they say no, he has a challenging behavior. And they give in again restarting that cycle. But when he's with us? Total sweetheart.

Oh yeah. I definitely realise it's not easy as the parent. I often remind myself when I get frustrated with some parents that they're just doing what they feel they have to in order to survive. It's a lot easier for me to tell a parent to ignore a challenging behavior when it's not my child crying or it's not my sentimental valuables being broken or when I know that I only have to wait it out for an hour versus possibly having to wait out a behavior for several hours.

I'll be honest, I'm not sure if you're being sarcastic or sincere but I'm guessing sincere based on your post history. So I'll respond sincerely. I agree. I can't imagine living in a world where nearly everyone thinks and communicates differently than I do and then being told that there's something wrong with me because I don't behave the same way as everyone else. I've found that often people think that my job is to "fix" people with autism. And I think that's very wrong. I'm not "fixing" anyone. Instead, I believe what I'm doing is teaching these kids a new way to communicate what they want and need so they can more easily navigate this world in which most people see things differently than they do. But to get back to your point, yeah. I have no idea what it's like. I mentioned the difficulty parents have because I can communicate more easily with parents than with the kids I work with and so I understand their point of view more readily.

I just had a baby four months ago. I'd rather have found out while pregnant than after when I'm trying to handle a newborn and hormonal fluctuations and sleep deprivation. There's no good time to tell someone that their SO is cheating on them, but being pregnant doesn't mean she shouldn't know.
So there is hope? I keep trying to control my appetite so I don't get stuck in the habit of eating constantly when I stop breastfeeding, but any attempts to control it seem to make it worse.

I agree. Healthy people don't generally just walk in and ask for counseling. They potentially don't want to think about it or face their own demons. After I was raped, I avoided anything that even remotely alluded to rape. Then I moved into a state in which I mentally (thankfully I never said these things out loud) degraded anyone who mentioned rape because I projecting my own insecurities and hatred of myself onto anyone who was able to speak up and who refused to be silenced. Since then I have acknowledged my rape out loud (and not just to a shitty counselor who didn't believe me) and I'm much less likely to project my insecurities about myself due to my rape on those who are more open about their experience with sexual assault. It's a lot easier to degrade others rather than face your own fears and insecurities. Edit: a misspelling

I'm glad that this is a possibility because it can lead to great things (though I am also annoyed that some people take advantage if this and can get into such a sensitive role very easily). In my hospital, we have two lactation consultants. I really only know one of them well and she is amazing. She's been doing this for many years and keeps up with current research and I'm sad that she's retiring in less than a year. But anyways, along with the two lactation consultants, many nurses in L amp;D were technically also lactation consultants through a similar course I believe. They wore pink scrubs and if you planned on breastfeeding, they made sure to have at least one in your delivery room when the baby was born to help you begin your breastfeeding journey and they could help you if you needed it in the middle of the night. Then, during regular hours, one of the lactation consultants would come visit you and help you if you needed it.

I fed my little one in the car before going into a store... My shirt was pulled down but realised after I got home that my bra and tank top weren't attached and my nursing pad was all crumpled up. That was attractive.

I came here to say postpartum depression. Which is more because I'm struggling with it now, but also struggling with admitting it out loud and getting help. It's hard when you get something you've wanted for a long time (a wonderful baby) and nothing is even going wrong for you and your baby is usually very calm... But all you feel is emptiness and sadness. And then people don't understand because "nothing [bad] happened" so there's no reason to be depressed.

Not around me. Before I moved, I regularly paid $2-3/lb for most deli meats and cheeses. Since I moved, most meats and cheeses are $6-9/lb. And I don't have to worry about buying more than I need and it going bad.

No, but I'd have to pay for a six pack of buns, all the veggies, the meats, and cheeses, and I can't toast my sandwich if I'm at work, and I have to make it. If I want a sandwich, $4.50 is worth it. It's cheapest for me to bring leftovers of something that cost me about $6 but got 3-4 meals out of.

Uhg. I hate this. I used to help an elderly lady with her cleaning and gardening for a couple years. And it evolved into me taking her to her doctor appointments and grocery shopping. We always took her car and somehow, she always just happened to have things scheduled around lunch time so we always had to stop and she insisted on buying. When I got married and moved away, my sister took over and told me the elderly lady continued to insist on buying lunch. She passed away early this year, but I'll always think of her when I see a Bob Evans or a Wendy's as those were get favorite places to eat.

I work with kids with developmental and physical disabilities and they often can't verbally consent to me touching them even when necessary (transferring to/from wheelchairs, toileting help). But I've found that most of the kids seem a lot more at ease when I talk them through what I'm going to do and where I'm going to touch them as I help them. I can't imagine someone who intentionally touches people to make them uncomfortable working with people with disabilities. It pisses me off to see someone so blatantly disrespected but it makes my blood boil to think of someone doing the same thing to people who can't stand up for themselves.

This is why I searched online for the check list that my pediatrician uses and printed it out. I already work with data (specifically with kids with autism and have run assessments) and so it's important to me to test every item before I say yes, sometimes, or no on the paper. It's hard to be accurate when you're filling those things out in the waiting room with your kid distracted by the unfamiliar environment.
An erection is a physical reaction to stimulation. It is not a sign of consent. Women sometimes orgasm during rape. That also does not mean consent has been given.
Probably. But it still needed to be said because unfortunately there are people who believe that.

We used to use mayonnaise because we lived in Papua New Guinea and the chemical treatments were hard to get and expensive if you did get it. So when there was a lice epidemic going around, you often saw a bunch of kids running around outside with their hair slathered in mayonnaise and held up on top of their heads with saran wrap. And of course everyone owned nit combs. Pretty sure my mom still has four of them "just in case" even though we're all adults now.

When I worked in fast food my manager was always really proud of her workers going further in their education (really anyone who worked hard). I know it frustrated her that some of her best employees were ones working to pay for college because they always moved on after they graduated, but she always worked with us on scheduling around classes, exams, and internships. I miss working for her sometimes. She also was never dramatic about who was or wasn't going to college so it didn't feel overdone or like she was trying to shame anyone. As far as I know, she's now a district manager for several stores.
My only disagreement is that there's no nose on the second picture for my son to jam his fingers up and no mouth for him to stick his fingers in and pull.

My son just turned one two weeks ago. I've loved watching him learn and grow. It's like he was a wiggly potato for so long and then suddenly BAM! He's rolling, then crawling, walking, running, dancing, pointing, singing... It's amazing. His first word besides mama and dada was cat... I could hardly believe it when I first heard it even though he clearly understood what it meant and was using it correctly. My heart fills up and wants to explode with joy because of that kid. Damn. Babies are amazing.

Not as light hearted as other answers here, but I work at a school in a classroom with kids with disabilities. I keep snacks in my car in case there's ever a reason that I'd have to take any of the kids and run. I've found that snacks can be very effective in calming kids in an emergency. I also keep toys in my car for the same reason. I also tend to keep a back up battery for my phone with me in case of lock down.

Hah. I hadn't thought of it like that before. No worries. I just want to be able to drive to a safe place without worrying that a kid will be too upset for me to safely drive in case of an active shooter emergency in our school. Looking back I feel that I need to edit this comment to add that kids with disabilities in general are not dangerous or unsafe. But as with any other kid, there's always the chance that in a situation like this there will be crying and screaming and potentially flailing of arms and legs which can be distracting and make it unsafe to drive.
Active shooter potentially.

This is a shot in the dark, but would it maybe help if you could get a kid's doctor kit and start playing with her with those instruments? Make it really silly and fun. Let her use them on you, dolls, stuffed animals, other adults. Then take one or two of those toys to public restrooms with you and let her play with them while you change her. If that works you could try taking the toys with you to the doctor's office.

Hello! I'm 25F. I originally started working on losing weight in 2017 and I lost about 20lb before getting pregnant with my son. Since then between pregnancy and nursing I gained 36lb. So now that I'm done nursing I'm ready to buckle down and get to a healthy weight. I've lost 16 so far - 100 more to go. I'm doing CICO and I try to get to the gym at least 3 times a week, but now that good weather is coming I'm looking forward to walking around town and hiking with my husband and son. ETA: This is my first challenge and I'm so excited!

Alternatively, if you have time, remove the child until they're calm and then return to the shopping. Just never give in if they're asking for something tangible. And in the future when going to the same store, don't talk about the last negative experience they had there. Let it go. It's a new day, a new chance. Obviously it's generally better to have a reinforcement plan in place before entering the store, "first we'll do all the shopping then we'll get/do something fantastic". Doesn't even have to be anything much - as long as the kid wants it. Plus set the kid up for success as much as possible in the beginning. Go right after nap/meal time so there in the best possible mood. Take that fun (preferably quiet and small and within reason) toy into the store, what's the kid hurting? Sorry about the long comment, but behavior management/modification is my job and I love to talk about it.

Wow! Good work with the 5lb! Nursing one is hard, I can't imagine tandem nursing. I always hated when people would talk about how the weight falls off when you're nursing because I couldn't lose any weight without losing my supply - I actually gained 15lb and it's a miracle that that's all it was. You're doing great, keep it up! :)

My goal is top be more active over all. It'll be good practice for when school is out for the summer. I'm hoping that my favorite t shirt will fit by the time summer starts - which is also the last day of the challenge and if I hit my challenge goal, the t shirt should fit. A little beyond this challenge, I'm really hoping that this challenge will push me and keep my motivation up because I want to hit my big goal in November when new staff photos are taken for IDs.

Ugh. Yeah, last night he woke up twice. But he was mostly quiet and passing by himself. Hopefully they both start sleeping through the night every night.

My son decided I didn't need to sleep from 11:30-12:30 last night plus he didn't want to go to bed and it was an early day so i only got 5.5 hours of sleep. WRITING.TITLE: At what point should you eat back some (if any) of your exercise calories?
WRITING.TEXT: Maybe it's a silly question but I couldn't find an answer in my (admittedly short) search. The number of calories that I can eat to maintain a 1000 calorie deficit is 1730. Lately I've been actually doing pretty well on some days with moving and exercising so according to LoseIt, I will have a "bonus" 1000-1400 calories from exercise. I don't want to up my activity level because I'm not consistent in moving that much, but I also don't want to get myself in trouble for eating too few calories since I'm already at a 1000 calorie deficit.

I don't know. I have my fitbit connected and it goes off of that. I don't generally eat my exercise calories (or if I do I do the half thing) but I also don't want to somehow hurt myself since they say that anything over 2lb (-1000 calories) isn't sustainable.

That's a good plan. I more my TDEE is going down - It's already down 60 calories. Like I said to someone else, I don't generally eat my exercise calories, and if I do it's only half, I just don't want to cause problems for myself.
Gotcha. Yeah, there was a bit when I was feeling pretty ragged, but that was when I was first starting and I figured it was just my body getting used to all the changes.
Well in that case, great! I'll just keep avoiding eating them and hopefully the weight will melt off faster.

I've managed to log two days at a much higher step rate than normal. I've been walking on my 15 minute break instead of sitting on my phone and when I take the kid I work with to the cardio room I work out with him instead of half assedly peddling on the bike. I've also noticed that the leg strength exercises my friend and I do have been giving us more endurance for running. On a more personal (but related) front, I convinced my friend that I workout with to join the challenge. She's on the DADA team but we're holding ourselves more accountable to going to gym now that we're both competing. And I convinced her to buy a tape measure to record inches lost since she was discouraged about not losing weight.

Boo work and pumping! Actually, boo having to go back to work while still nursing making pumping necessary. I don't generally give unsolicited advice (at least I try not to), but I found that a steady supply of water and small bags of portioned high fat/high protein snacks like nuts and avocado were helpful for keeping my supply up without gaining as much weight as well staving off some of the nursing munchies.

Small goal: Restrain myself over Easter. I'm already okay with the fact that I'll probably eat at maintenance on Sunday and I've been trying to save calories this week in case I do go over some. I'm okay with not eating candy, it's the big meal that gets me. NSV: I pulled the wrong jeans out of my drawer this morning and tried them on for the hell of it and they fit! These are my pre pregnancy jeans! They're actually a tiny bit loose. I haven't noticed my jeans sizes changing because I've been living in leggings.
My plates said microwave safe on the package...
I logged!

I want to go to the park with my husband and son. Maybe go out for lunch somewhere together. And I don't want to be the one to have to initiate things we do together as a family. Tbh, I don't know if my husband even realizes it. He relies on Amazon to remind him of big holidays.

Pretty much same here. Only exception is our anniversary, but my husband also doesn't really like celebrating holidays. We're still getting on the same page as far as me loving to celebrate holidays and him thinking they're kinda pointless.
Ooh. I like that.

That's definitely a good point. I do try to encourage whatever he does plan, because he does plan things sometimes and he really does do a great job when he does. I'm just at the place where I know he likely isn't going to want to do anything that day whether I plan it out not honestly.
Yes and no. More that we're still learning how to communicate about something that I find important when he sees it as just another day (and yes, that includes father's day).
I'm so sorry to hear about your wife's friend as well as her social support. I wish you and your family the best.

I kind of think that as long as you put genuine thought and time into your choice (and it's a place she's shown interest in before) that it does in that case put the ball in her court. If you want to avoid that you could have a couple of suggestions ready and start by naming your top choice and if she says no suggest the next choice.
True. Good thing he knows this is what I want. Not hinted at. He's been told in clear words that I want him to plan mother's day.
Because I love them and don't really get to see either of them very much because my husband and I work very different schedules and only recently have had a day off together.

WRITING.TITLE: NSV: I didn't make excuses and I didn't give up
WRITING.TEXT: Today I went to the gym after work as usual planning to meet my gym partner there. I walked halfway to the door when I realised I didn't have my key pass card. Okay, they'll sign me in. Got signed in and realised I forgot my water bottle in the car. Went back and grabbed it. Got changed and realised I don't have my travel bag with hair ties and no extras floating around. I was about to text my gym partner and ask her to bring me an extra when she called and something had come up so she had to cancel. No biggie, it happens. Finally went to the front desk and ask if they had any, had to go scrounge up a quarter in my car to buy one, and then I finally started my workout. But here's the thing. A few months ago I would have given up after I realised I had no hair tie and no gym partner that day. I would have maybe messed around with some small weights a bit so I wouldn't look like I left as soon as I arrived. Instead I carried on to W2D1 of c25k (which I accidentally closed halfway through and had to restart). I ended up going 3.85 miles and being on the treadmill for an hour. It felt really good to not make excuses and to carry on even when I kept forgetting things. So don't let little things get in your way. Find a way to step past excuses. It's worth it in the end. Oh, and here's the best part. While I realise the importance of learning to be accountable to myself, my biggest motivation to see the workout through was this community - specifically my team for the challenge. The community is so welcoming and supportive and competitive within itself that I wanted to continue to do my part. So thanks to this whole big wonderful supportive community.

I still eat burger buns but usually only the bottom half. It's tortillas that really get me. I still love tortillas, but I don't love spending half my meal calories on them when I can make it into a salad.

I'm pretty sure I frustrate my bread selling husband because he used to bring home a bunch of different breads for us to enjoy but lately I just don't really eat sandwiches. I really eat toast anymore either. I do still eat bagels, but not every morning and if I do, I just make a smaller lunch. It helps that I like the laughing cow spreadable cheese on it so only 30 calories vs the 125 I'd probably get from butter.

Excuses are so easy to make and sometimes working out is so hard, it's not surprising that excuses seem the best in the moment. My gym has a sign that says "When I lost all my excuses I find my results". And a lot of times it's the little results I've been seeing that I have remind myself of whenever I start making excuses. And if you have a chance, maybe swing by a Wal-Mart or target and pick up a cheap set of headphones just to get you through until your good ones get to you.
Haha. No, I'm actually on Transfiguration, but my friend is on DADA.

Weather is supposed to be beautiful this weekend so I'm planning on taking my kiddo on some walks - hopefully my husband and my mom will be able to join for some of them. I usually get my lowest activity on the weekends so this will be good. Today I'm going to workout after work, then go on a hike, and then walk some more with my mom when I go to pick up my kiddo. I can't change much about the rest of my week, but I feel like those pieces will boost my activity for this week a lot.

I don't think my mom knows. I asked her and she said that once they get married they don't have periods anymore (because they're expected to have children right away and pretty much until they no longer can, especially the ones that can't wear underwear). So maybe free bleed? My mom suggested maybe a belt to attach the rags to hold them up. ETA: She said there's no way they wear tampons or store bought pads because those are definitely too fancy. There might be some groups of Amish that allow them, but I'm talking about the really strict groups.

My husband and I bought a house because we could see the prices of rent and mortgages around us increasing at a high rate. So we went and got a mortgage. At the time our mortgage was about $200 dollars higher than our rent had been. That was a year and a half ago. Our friend who lives in the same apartments that we had been in thought we were being stupid to invest in a slightly higher mortgage when we sometimes struggled to make rent (aka we couldn't go party with her because we needed that money for rent). She's now frustrated because rent has increased too high for her to afford (higher than our mortgage) but she also can't find an affordable mortgage now either. Not that everyone can afford to switch from rent to owning, but we were in a place where it cost basically the same and are fortunate to have good credit and were eligible for a program that got us a lower interest rate despite having no down payment.

So today I decided to make a goal of 35k steps. It meant I had to be moving pretty much every moment I could at work, pacing when my kiddos we're doing their own thing, walking further to the bathroom, and of course continuing my walks/runs during my breaks. And then the gym afterwards and waking around my parents' neighborhood until they got home with my kid. But then I was just so close to 40k that I decided to push for that. And I did it! I got 40k steps in one day!
I'm logged! I'll log todays steps/activity tomorrow morning.

One thing that has definitely changed for me is the number of steps I take. My Fitbit average was about 9000 per day before the challenge and is currently about 18,000 a day. Typically during the work week I get 20,000-25,000 steps a day. I'm still trying to work on increasing my weekends. The habit that changed is that I walk or on my breaks during work and I'm not consistent with going to the gym or hiking at least four days a week. I'm a little concerned going into the summer (I work at a school) that my fitness is going to tank because I won't be forced to leave the house every day. I've been making a plan for how to combat that. My friend and I are planning on hiking every day during the week and going to the gym once or twice a week when my husband will be home to care for our kid. And my husband wants to do additional hiking once he's off work. But I've learned during this challenge that if I set a goal for myself and I tell someone, that I'm more honest with myself and more consistent with working towards my goals.

I really wish I had taken more time to appreciate this. I did have moments where we'd be up in the middle of the night with the room only lit by the glow of the TV and I'd just stare at my son in fascination that I made him, my heart just hurting because it was so full of love - especially during the times that he'd be nursing and keeping eye contact with me.

I didn't hit my goal, I was 2lb away but still lost 13lb during this challenge. I learned a lot about what my body can do. I went from an average of 9000 daily steps to an average of about 20,000 daily steps. I started jogging and I can jog for 12 minutes now. I didn't push myself to see how much I could do before but with the motivation of needing more steps with the same amount of time available for working out, I pushed myself to jog longer to get more steps. Seeing what my body can do has helped me respect my body more and want to take care of it more - including eating well. But most of all, I've been learning to relax and that it's okay to take maintenance days every now and then. It helps to be reminded that I won't always be restricting calories but it's also a good reminder that even when I'm not longer restricting calories I don't have carte blanche to eat myself sick - I'm still responsible for caring for this amazing hard working body. I did hit one goal though - one of my favorite t shirts fits me again! I'm planning on taking an after picture and posting it on discord at some point soon with my before picture from the very beginning of the challenge.

Couple of NSVs and a SV: My wedding ring is getting to be too big! But even better, I'm starting to feel like myself again. I'm still at least 70lbs out from my goal, but I look in the mirror and I recognize the woman I see in there. I'm at the weight I was at when I got pregnant. Ever since I got pregnant I felt huge. I know it was mostly bloating and hormones, but now that I'm back down to a weight that I recognize, I'm more confident again and I don't feel like I'm being chased by the extra weight that I "chose" to add by having my son.

This happens so much with developmentally disabled people and boy does it piss me off. I work in a school in the life skills room and we have our kids interact with neurotypical peers as much as possible and do you know who talks to our kids in a baby voice the most? Some of our own fucking staff. Other students are great and treat our kids the same way they would probably treat each other (except nicer, they don't swear in our classroom) but I worry about them seeing staff treat our kids like babies and beginning to imitate that behavior. And yes, I have called staff out on it but nothing changes.

My MIL tried to pressure me into circumcising my son. Granted, my SIL didn't have her son circumcised and then didn't really take good care of him so he ended up needing the surgery at four years old because it got so infected, so I can see why she thinks not circumcising is bad. I told my MIL that we've done our research and we feel more comfortable not circumcising and she let it go after 3-4 conversations about it. Thankfully not circumcising is becoming a lot more common in the US and I was able to find a pediatrician that supports my decision and also knows how to care for an infant's uncircumcised penis because I've heard some not so great stories of pediatricians giving bad advice about foreskin care.

I think the biggest problem is that people treat people with disabilities with pity rather than compassion. And acting in pity, they try to bubble wrap them from the world and treat them like they're helpless babies rather than people with different challenges. Acting in compassion (like it sounds like you do) means consciously acting in ways that acknowledges that they have challenges with some areas (loud noises, routine changes, etc) and not being a dick but also not preventing them from experiencing the world because of limitations you've placed on them rather than the limitations they've find that they're comfortable with.

I agree. I've caught myself getting stuck in doing things how I've always done them rather than adapting to what the person I'm working with needs. It's also been a struggle I've had since starting in a new position last fall because I've been working with some paras who have been in this job for years and they pushed back hard when I worked to change how we approach working with some of the kids because it meant our job went from more of a babysitting type job to a job that actively worked to improve the kids' skills (ya know, what we were hired for and get paid to do).

I work with a kid at school who likes to talk about guns and shooting in video games. I have to remind him a lot that while guns are interesting and it's fun to pretend you're in a video game, that's something we talk about at home, not at school because I worry that the wrong person could overhear him and turn it into an unnecessary problem.

I plan on talking about what I'm doing while I'm helping my kid clean himself until he's old enough to take a bath by himself and hopefully he'll learn from that and actually do it, but our pediatrician said that once my kid is old enough, he'll talk to him about hygiene and taking care of his foreskin. Which is great because I don't have a penis and my husband was circumcised so neither of us has had any experience with caring for an uncut penis before.

For fuck's sake. Even my son, who isn't yet two, understands when I tell him that it's not okay to hit people when you're upset. Using violence creates fear, not respect. I'd rather my child take longer to learn how to behave well and him love and respect me than for him to stop having inappropriate behavior quickly but him only fear me.

Just because other people don't have great behavior doesn't mean my son can't learn how to treat others well. I know that I'm not going to be the only influence in his life, and I won't be surprised if/when he does get into fights, but knowing how to use words is a much harder skill to learn and I'd rather focus on teaching him that skill so that when his circle of influence is expanded and he runs into people who prefer to use violence, he will have more tools than just his fists.

I'm a behavior therapist who has worked with older kids/adults who learned to go straight to violence as a problem solving method. Yeah, it takes time, but we've helped these people learn how to control their violent behavior. Without smacking them across the head, as the other commenter suggested. I'm pretty sure I have a higher than average knowledge of how to influence a child's behavior. And sure, if my son shows problematic behavior when he's that age, I'll work with his teachers/adults in his life to implement a plan on how to correct that behavior, but honestly, behavior that could be considered harassment when he's older will probably be developmentally appropriate at a young age and I will address it as it comes up.

Oh hell yeah. Always address behavior as soon as it is safe and preferably after everyone involved has has a chance to reset and calm themselves. Sure it can be a pain in the ass if you have to put something on hold to address a behavior or to ignore a behavior when it's distracting but needs to be ignored, but having an immediate healthy purposeful response/nonresponse (even if it's a neutral response until the kid is able to regain control of themselves) is the one of the first steps in correcting a behavior before it becomes a huge problem. And I realise that we're probably not going to see eye to eye on this, but I think that what you're labeling as "new age" methods are more effective and should be the first response rather than physical punishment.

My experience is a little different in that the man who raped me was my boyfriend, but after it happened (and after I finally left him a few months later) I threw myself into working out without working on my mental state which led to unhealthy calorie restriction which turned into binge eating when another man started to show interest in dating me. Since then I've gotten my mental health into a better state - not always great, but definitely better. What helps me with the weight loss is that I'm also doing strength training because even though I know it likely wouldn't have made a difference, I like the idea that I could fight him off if I would need to. That doesn't mean that I don't still struggle at times. I have to be very careful that I don't start restricting calories too much again and some days I can hardly get out of bed and have to fight the urge to eat all the junk food because that small part of my brain that tells me that I don't deserve to be happy with my body. But I'm lucky to have a supportive husband (who knows everything) who encourages me and reminds me that my worth is so much more than what my body does or doesn't look like. I'm not sure if that's the kind on response you were looking for when you posted but that's my experience in a nutshell and I'm willing to answer questions if you have any you want to ask.

Technically yes on the second part, because being anorexic means that the person is underweight regardless of cause. Anorexia Nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by eating too few calories and is considered a psychological disorder. It has nothing to do with the current weight of the person with AN though being underweight can be a symptom. However, in the US at least, anorexia and being anorexic have both become commonly used terms for Anorexia Nervosa which means when being used generally and not medically, when someone says anorexic, they are usually talking about the eating disorder, not the characteristic of being very unhealthily underweight.

I worry so much that my depression is going to affect my relationship with my son. I mostly have it and my panic attacks managed, but there are still days that I just sit on the couch and don't have the energy to do anything when I should be on the floor playing with him. And then the guilt other moms put on moms about screen time makes it worse because when I'm having a day when I can barely get off the couch, the best thing I can do in that moment is turn on the TV for him. Thankfully I live close to my parents and they can generally take him when I need a day or two to get back on track. I'm working on finding a therapist, but I've been to three in the past that weren't great and it makes it hard to keep looking for a good one that I can work with. And yes very much on not touching during panic attacks! My husband has learned how to best approach when I'm having one, which is to just talk to me calmly and every once in a while ask if he can hold me until I can nod my head. I still flinch a lot then too but it's better than me taking a swing at him. Also, for what it's worth, I generally can function well through my depression, which made me deny that I had it for a long time. Sure I was dealing with my own voice in my head constantly telling me when I messed up and reminding me that everyone hates me, but I thought that it was pretty normal because I always thought depression was being completely unable to function. It manifested for me more like anxiety and I had to get everything done and it had to be done right and when I couldn't do it, I would just crash. I turned to self harm to give me energy (sounds weird, I know) to keep me going so that I wouldn't ruin the next thing I had to do which really put me in a vicious cycle. It wasn't until I started having panic attacks after my ex, who exploited my mental illness, raped me that I began to recognize that something was seriously wrong with me and I started trying to get help, which is hard when you don't want anyone in your personal life to know. Like I said, it's mostly managed now with most of the credit going to my wonderful husband.

Yeah, I'm at the point where I don't really care if people see them. They are what they are and I don't self harm anymore but I hate when people comment on them. Not because I'm ashamed of them, but because the people who comment on them generally start asking about them and I don't like to talk about why I did it which is what they generally want to know. It feels voyeuristic and it makes me feel gross. Either that or they get all judgemental and act like I'm still the same person who made those scars without knowing how far I've come and again, makes me feel gross.
I think it's to sort out real gold (won't be attracted to the magnet) from gold plated metal.

Okay, genuine question, are thrift store clothes considered old..? Because my husband and I are considering fostering in a few years (when our house is big enough to give a kid or two their own room/s) but while I occasionally buy new clothes (underwear, shoes, socks, good sales), most of my wardrobe is from thrift stores. Is that frowned upon when fostering? Because I have a hard time paying high prices for new clothes when you can get good clothes at a thrift store for reasonable prices. But I also don't want any kids that we would foster to think that we're buying them cheap clothes because we want to pocket the rest of the money.
Gotcha. I just know there can be a stigma about buying used clothes even when kids are biologically your own, and I wasn't sure how far that extended into the world of fostering.

And if you use my medical center, you get to send your insurance after them every single time you get a bill because they will charge you for things that insurance covers because they either billed it wrong or because insurance paid it and now they want us to pay for it too (both have happened to us) plus they're notorious for double billing something you paid months before. My mom liked to tell me that my son is "all boy" because he likes to climb and get dirty and be stereotypically a boy. Sometimes she'll also say "he's just like his mom" when he's doing the same things because I was a dirty, running, climbing kid too. One day when she said "he's all boy" I asked her if that meant I was a boy when I was a kid since he's also just like me. Haven't heard the all boy comment in a while now. But seriously, props to my mom who was raised conservatively with gender stereotypes but has been starting to change some of those views.

I became someone I hated during the Kavanaugh hearings. It took me a while to realise that the reason I was acting bitter and angry and having trouble getting out of bed again wasn't just my depression, but it was me reacting to my own fears and trauma that I thought I had dealt with. I love my husband and he tries so hard to be supportive, but he just doesn't get it. He couldn't figure out why it was bothering me so much. It wasn't descriptions of the allegations against Kavanaugh that was bothering me, it was the victim bashing and people around me refusing to consider that it might have happened. The same people that I either a) refused to tell about me being raped because I knew they'd make jokes/wouldn't believe me/would likely side with my rapist or b) people who knew what happened to me and acted like I brought it on myself. Not sure what my point was except to just get that out. It's funny how candidly I can talk about what happened to me on the internet to strangers but I can't say the words out loud to my husband or a therapist.

I needed to read this. There have been many times that I've cried because we're OAD and it wasn't until recently that I started to realise it's because I'm sad that I didn't get to have the pregnancy experience I wanted. I didn't have my mom around to talk to and feel the kicks. I didn't get to have the waiting game of when will I go into labor. I know I should be so grateful that I didn't get preeclampsia until I was late enough into the game (37+1) that they could induce as soon as they discovered it, but I still mourn for the lost experiences that I looked forward to. But I'm starting to come to terms with the fact that I'm not really wanting to have another baby, I'm wanting those missed experiences.
Seconding Mama Lupe's. Took me a long time to find them and I'll never go back.

This is partially why I buy at thrift stores. You can generally find quality clothes that still have a lot of life in them for a lot cheaper than you'd find them in a regular store. The biggest problem with thrift stores right now is that they've suddenly become what seems like a fad and thrift stores have noticed and are starting to up their prices. But small local stores (so not Goodwill or, depending on your area, salvation army) still tend to have lower prices though you might have to put more work into going through the store. If you want to go to Goodwill or salvation army, they tend to have days that certain tag colors are half off or more.

I understand what you're saying with it being concerning, but it's really hard to question things when you're raised in an environment where you're pretty much taught that to try to understand things like abortion in a different way is to question God. That sounds like no big deal when you already don't believe in God, but it's terrifying when you've been taught your whole life that if you reject God and his ways you'll be sent to burn in hell along with all the other horrible people in the world. All the horrible people out there sinning who actually feel miserable because only God is joy. So if you question God's ways, you'll be miserable and a horrible person. That's why I didn't really start questioning a lot of things until after I was raped and terrified that I would get pregnant and be forced out of my Christian college and forced to raised a baby I didn't want. I got lucky and didn't get pregnant. But that's when I started questioning things. And I started getting better answers. Sure, I was miserable at first, but also relieved to realise that I was miserable when I believed in God, but at least now I felt free to experience my feelings without guilt. I guess what I'm saying is the brainwashing can be strong. But I also had people in my life that I thought I was trying to fix, who ended up being my support when I began to question things. Which is why I still hang out with people who believe differently than I do. They give me a different perspective and I try to give them mine. Sorry, really long response to say 'I agree with you, but this is why it was hard in my experience'.

Montana, where I wouldn't have expected prices to go up a lot. Shirts that I've seen at Walmart for $3 are at Goodwill for $3.99. Bigger brand shirts are generally $7.99 which isn't terrible if they're usually $20, but I probably could have gotten it brand new for $10 at some point. I've seen some stained stretched out brand names marked at $12.99. Dresses are starting to be base marked at $9.99 with brand items being marked at $24.99. I'll only buy coats in the summer because they're usually priced better, but in the winter I've seen them marked as $39.99 for a coat I could get new for $45. Good news is that means that things I want are more likely to make it to dollar day which is when I prefer to shop.

I work with people with developmental disabilities. I was being observed on my first couple of days at my last job which included helping a child with developmental disabilities use the toilet and when it came time to use the toilet I talked the kid through what I was going to do. "It's time to use the bathroom, I'm going to help you pull your pants down and then I'll help you sit on the toilet." I do this with all the people I work with (adults and kids) and my supervisor that day told me she knew I was definitely the right choice when she saw me talk the kid through what we were going to do because most people don't bother talking to the kids (and sometimes the adults) because they either think they won't understand or that they're just used to it happening so there's no reason to tell them.

Ripen them in a bag with an apple. The apple ripens them quickly and evenly. When I started doing this I pulled out one avocado and it was really soft and I thought I had over done it, but when I cut it open to check, it was the most perfect avocado I'd ever opened.

I use a plastic grocery bag because I couldn't find a small paper bag when I first did it. It depends on the avocado, but I generally check them every 12 hours or so. Some take just 12 hours, I've had some take closer to 48.

Babies are hard. Especially the first 8ish weeks before they start to smile. But education starts as soon as they're born. You can read to a baby and although the baby won't understand the words or the concept really, just reading to your infant jump-starts language development. And the best part is, when they're little, you can read literally anything you want to them. My husband read some Dracula to our son. I read my fantasy books to him. He didn't care. We were interacting with him and telling him stories. Now he's a toddler and I feel like all we ever read are the same three books. But you know what? He loves those books. And he loves sitting in his chair and pretending to read out loud to us. That was a bit of a tangent, but the point is - even if you don't feel like you're actively educating your baby, it's okay. They learn so much from just being with you and watching how you interact with other people and things in your environment. The baby stage shapes a lot of who they grow up to be.
